title: Today's most collectable luxuries: the ultimate wish list
text:
One caution: as a new car with 1960s safety specifications, the Zagato is not road legal, which is perhaps why Aston Martin will also throw in a modern DBS Zagato with every continuation.

An even more ambitious re-creation is due next year: the DB5 Goldfinger Edition, complete with original James Bond spy gadgets.

The MV Agusta Brutale 1000 Serie Oro: yours to ride away for a tad under $72,000.

MV Agusta Brutale 1000 Serie Oro

Legendary Italian motorcycle company MV Agusta has had its ups and downs through the years, but is very much up these days. That’s reflected in some of its most stylish, desirable and collectable motorcycles ever.

Brutale by name and nature, this “Gold Series” edition brings together a multitude of exotic materials and is described as the world’s most powerful naked sports bike.

If not in the mood to sample the race-bred 155kW engine spinning at a mad 13,450 revolutions per minute, you can simply park it and enjoy it as art.

Just 300 are being made, worldwide; the first in Australian showrooms should appear this month at $71,990 ride-away.

Advertisement

Fashion

Selected by Virginia van Heythuysen, AFR fashion director

Armadillo boot by Alexander McQueen

In October 2009, the late Alexander McQueen presented his last show, “Atlantis”, which included the Armadillo boot. There were models who refused to walk the show after seeing them – and you can see why.

Yours for around $100,000 – a pair of Alexander McQueen's Armadillo stiletto boots, featuring a 30cm heel.

Only 21 pairs of these oddly grotesque boots (with a teetering 30cm heel) were ever made, and Lady Gaga snapped up three pairs of them at auction for $US290,000 in 2015.

Not quite right for a nip down to the shops, they’re most definitely works of art.

Hermès scarf by Kermit Oliver

Retired postal worker and full-time artist Kermit Oliver is the only American artist to have designed scarves for storied French maison Hermès. Now 76, Oliver, who lives in Waco, Texas, has created 17 designs for the house and his intricate pieces can take up to a year to develop.

A Faune et Flore du Texas scarf by Hermès is a relative steal at about $3400.

He paints each on a 90cm x 90cm square of paper and sends them to Paris to be fashioned into scarves. This example, Faune et Flore du Texas, was first made in 1987, and you can snap one up for about $US2300 ($3378).

Advertisement

Jewellery

Selected by Fiona Frith, jewellery specialist at Bonhams Sydney

Torsade Diamond bangle by Suzanne Belperron

One of the most celebrated jewellery designers of the 20th century, French-born Suzanne Belperron was known for using feminine curves at a time when art deco’s hard edges reigned.

Suzanne Belperron's Torsade bangle last sold at auction for $294,000.

Unusual materials marked Belperron as an individual in her day, while her unique designs retain a contemporary feel almost 100 years later. This bangle, made in 1932, last sold at auction for £164,500 ($294,196). It’s a rare exemplar of Belperron’s earliest independent work, still demonstrative of her singular style.

Cocktail rings by Andrew Grima

Avant-garde even by today’s standards, British jewellery designer Andrew Grima has historically been overlooked. But as our cringe over 1960s and ’70s jewellery fades, we can expect a huge rise in his popularity. Grima’s use of unusual materials, such as ruby zoisite crystal, cobaltoan calcite, amethyst geode and polished chalcedony druzy, made him an original.

Cocktail ring by Andrew Grima – a diamond pendant by this British designer fetched about $4.8 million in 2017.

There have already been some impressive sales of his jewels – a fancy-coloured diamond pendant fetched £2,685,000 (about $4.8 million) in 2017. His cocktail rings and brooches will also command high prices in years to come.

Advertisement

Cartier Tutti Frutti bracelet

This enamel, gem-set and diamond bracelet is familiar to many due to Cartier’s blockbuster National Gallery of Australia exhibit in 2018. Cartier started experimenting with pieces inspired by Indian jewellery’s rich colours and carved gemstones as early as 1901, when it made a necklace for Queen Alexandra. By the 1930s, the Tutti Frutti collection was flourishing.

An art deco Tutti Frutti bracelet by Cartier last sold for about $828,000 in 2015.

This art deco bracelet, with more than 10 carats of diamonds, is unusual in its combination of colours and the clean lines of its graphic arrangement. It last sold for £458,500 in 2015 and would make a fine investment – or piece of wrist candy.

Design

Selected by Stephen Todd, AFR design editor

Atmos clock by Marc Newson for Jaeger-LeCoultre

Sydney-born Marc Newson has designed everything from luggage to samurai swords. His Lockheed Lounge, from 1987, fetched £2,434,500 on auction at Phillips, London, in April 2015 – the record for a piece of furniture by a living designer. One of Newson’s favourite pieces is his Atmos clock, designed for Jaeger-LeCoultre in 2008. “It’s as if it is a living thing,” he says.

Marc Newson's Atmos 568 clock in clear Baccarat crystal sells for $47,300.

Advertisement

Crafted from blue Baccarat crystal with rhodium-plated feet, the Atmos 566 is available in a limited edition of 28 (POA). The 568 in clear Baccarat crystal (shown above) is available in an open edition for $47,300, and sure to become an heirloom.

Nacho Carbonell’s sculptural furniture and lighting work, such as his Under a Light Tree seat, is being avidly collected.

Under A Light Tree seat by Nacho Carbonell

“I like to see objects as living organisms, imagining them coming alive and being able to surprise you with their behaviour,” says Spanish designer Nacho Carbonell – behaviour like the come-hither luminosity of the Under A Light Tree love-seat.

Conjured from branches of gnarled brass topped with metal mesh that floats like glowing foliage, it entices sitters as moths to its flame.

A graduate of the edgy Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands, Carbonell’s sculptural furniture and lighting work is exhibited and collected by an avid cognoscenti worldwide, and selected pieces are available through Carpenters Workshop Gallery (London, Paris, New York, San Francisco).

Bureau en Forme desk by Charlotte Perriand

Charlotte Perriand went largely unsung until a retrospective at London’s Design Museum in 1998 introduced a new generation to her work. She’s now considered one of the most important designers of the 20th century.

Charlotte Perriand's 1939 Bureau en Forme desk sold at auction for nearly $1.15 million in 2017.

For 10 years, Perriand worked alongside Le Corbusier and his cousin Pierre Jeanneret, devising game-changing chrome and leather furniture. In 1937, she set up her own studio, and her 1939 Bureau en Forme (Free-form desk) is a signature piece: a pinewood slab with two deep suspension drawers fronted by unpolished aluminium sheeting, on three angled legs. Artcurial sold it at auction in October 2017 for €703,400.

Advertisement

Diapason chaise longue by Giovanni de Lucchi and Titti Saracino

Some objects accrue value because of scarcity, some because of the way in which they encapsulate an era. The Diapason chaise longue does both.

Originally produced in 1973 by Elleduemila, a division of Italian manufacturer Lenzi that was operational from 1971 to 1975, only a small quantity were made and it has been out of production ever since. The way its brutal-chic concrete base cups the vicious stainless-steel blade that forms the lounger evokes a Cold War James Bond villain in his superlair. Available through Sydney rare-design importer Don Cameron.

Wine & Spirits

Selected by Max Allen, AFR wine writer

Penfolds Block 42 Cabernet Sauvignon

Possibly the most precious of all Penfolds vineyards is the small patch of 130-year-old cabernet sauvignon vines on the company’s Kalimna property in the Barossa Valley called Block 42. Wine made from these vines is bottled only on very rare occasions – just twice in the past 25 years – and can mature and improve in the cellar for decades, making it increasingly attractive to collectors. A bottle of the inaugural 1964 Bin 707 cabernet, made using Block 42 grapes, recently sold at auction for $13,980; the 1996 and 2004 vintages of Block 42 are a snip in comparison, selling for between $500 and $1000.

From left: Penfolds Block 42 Cabernet Sauvignon; 2005 Champagne Jacquesson Aÿ – Vauzelle Terme; 1993 GlenDronach Single Cask Bottling #392 Single Malt.

2005 Champagne Jacquesson Aÿ Vauzelle Terme

As you’d expect, the list of top champagnes compiled by wine-searcher.com (based on the website’s huge database of critics’ scores) is dominated by well-established, well-known names: Krug, Cristal, Dom Pérignon, and so on. The notable exception is this rich, savoury example of the blanc de noir style from Jacquesson, established only 40 years ago. Despite tiny production – it comes from just one acre of pinot noir vines – it’s one of the most attractively priced champagnes in the top-10 list. At $850 (imported by cellarhand.com.au), a magnum of this costs less than a standard bottle of half the others.

Advertisement

1993 GlenDronach Single Cask Bottling #392 Single Malt

On February 12, 1993, barrel number 392 was just one of many casks filled with newly made whisky at the GlenDronach distillery in the Scottish Highlands. Twenty-six years later, master blender Dr Rachel Barrie has selected the contents of that barrel to be sold exclusively in Australia through The Whisky List; there are just 659 bottles available at $700 each. It is an absolutely extraordinary whisky: brooding, dark, woody aromatics, like smouldering caramel in an oak-panelled library, opening out to flavours of dried orange peel, violets, cloves, sweet heather and rich, roasted walnuts. A superb single malt.

Watches

Selected by Bani McSpedden, AFR watch editor

What watch would I recommend to a budding collector? First and foremost, it’s the one you’d love to have on your wrist – and you’d know what that is better than I would. On the other hand, if you’re looking for something that will escalate in value as an investment piece, the safest bets – vintage or new – have been watches from Patek Philippe and Rolex Daytonas and Submariners, with Richard Mille more recently joining the ranks of the sought-after.

Have these watches peaked? Only time will tell, but you might also consider early chronographs from Breitling, Heuer and Longines, or from brands best known to aficionados, such as Universal Genève. Then there’s the budget consideration, and the advice here is simple: buy the best you can afford.

Originally priced in the hundreds, a 1957 Rolex GMT-Master Reference 6542 is now valued from $120,000 to $200,000.

Sydney collector Andre Christian nominates the 1957 Rolex GMT-Master Reference 6542 as a Holy Grail collectable. It’s the very first GMT-Master and was the result of a collaboration between the Pan Am airline and Rolex. The watch of choice for Pan Am’s intercontinental pilots, it’s distinguishable by a bakelite bezel and has been seen on the wrists of Fidel Castro and Picasso – and Pussy Galore in the 1964 James Bond film Goldfinger. You’re looking at $120,000-$200,000 for a watch that originally sold for a few hundred dollars.

Advertisement

The Universal Genève Tri-Compax Reference 12552 was first released in 1944, and range from $12,000 to $80,000 in value.

If six figures is beyond your budget, the Universal Genève Tri-Compax Reference 12552 might prove a timely investment. The first triple calendar moonphase chronograph wristwatch, it was announced at the 1944 Basel Watch Fair to commemorate the brand’s 50th anniversary. US president Harry S Truman wore a gold one at the Potsdam Conference in 1945. Versions with a white dial range from $12,000 to $20,000; with the black dial, from $60,000 to $80,000.

Prices for the Gallet Clamshell Flying Officer are rising – up to $30,000.

The Gallet Clamshell Flying Officer is another gem from the 1940s. It’s one of the first water-resistant chronographs from one of the earliest (circa 1466) clock makers. It was worn by high-ranking officers in the US Army Air Force during World War II, as well as, again, President Truman – obviously a watch aficionado. Its value? $35,000 and climbing.

The heritage issue of LUXURY is out on Friday, September 6 inside The Australian Financial Review. Follow LUXURY on Instagram.
description: If you're in the business of starting your own collection – cars, wine, jewels, whatever – start at the top, with toys that truly fit the money-can't-buy bill.
